What does everybody want to see? Well, it's actually not what you would think. It's not like there's a
best of that people want to come in on. It's really the thing that I also didn't anticipate is that
emotional feeling of following along with the current time during the anniversary of the mission
really has an emotional effect. I know it does on me, but it's really resonated with people online.
So during the 50th anniversary of Apollo 11, this was going bananas. And the amount of bandwidths
being downloaded. And we had a million concurrent viewers watching Apollo 11 in real time. And
that included like a million. Yeah, like they're like all teamed in listening to the radio type
thing. Then they would leave and come back. It followed literally the ratings of the actual
mission in the 50 years earlier. It was a little bit showed up for launch. Lots of people showed
up for first steps on the men. And then a few people paid attention for reentry and recovery.
And then for the rest of it, it was like troughs. So it would go up to tens of thousands of those
moments down to troughs of hundreds of people that were tuned in. And you could just come back,
just drop in, hey, what are they doing now? And you just open the website and it would like,
oh, they're not waking up for another four hours. I'll come back in four hours and see what they're
going to do today. I've got one more question I'd like to hit you with. It's an odd question,
but I think I'm sensing you'll see what I'm driving at. What does the moon landing mean?
Well, it's come to mean a lot more in hindsight than I think it did at the time.
I was just talking to my good friend, Stephen Slater yesterday. And he pointed out that this
was just an ephemeral thing that was happening at the time. It was like anything else that was
happening. People paid attention and the world stopped possibly for 10 minutes when
Neil stepped onto the surface of the moon. But the looking back has shown us that this is what
could happen when 400,000 people all with a common purpose work together to make something happen.
It really shows the best of what we can be when we work together. And that's the thing that keeps
coming back to me with looking at this material and then also looking forward to our return to the
moon, which is on the table right now for us to do. And everybody getting very excited about
rallying together to make something like that happen again. This is like a living metaphor for
the power of multiple processors. And in a way, it's a bit of a pushback on the American rugged
individualism thing, which I really, really like. I love the idea of the individual versus nature
and using the one processor to defeat things. But there's a glass ceiling to how much even the
best mind can process. How many problems the best mind can solve. And as you've been talking
about all of this, I'm picturing all of the areas of specialization represented by not just the
individuals at those consoles that we can click on and listen in on, but their entire teams behind
them, all these people who've done things just like you've done, Ben, putting time into nurturing
this skill set to being able to think philosophically and ethically and from a problem-solving perspective
to figure out what they do know, what they don't know, what they can't know, what they need somebody
else to know, where I would need somebody else's 20 years of investment to fill in this blank spot
that I don't have enough lifetime or processing power to get. You put 400,000 processors on that
mental processors, all organized in the right way. One, it's amazing that it took that much human
processing to defeat something that to a simpleton like me looks like, we'll just put a big rocket
on something and point it at that ball in the sky. You should get there, it should be fine.
Well, no, it's not. I mean, so one, it's a testimony to how big the problem was.
And two, I'm really moved and appreciate your observation as to the power of carefully directed
shared processing. People traded their life energy, their creativity, their mind space,
their mind time to put that boot on that rock. And it's incredible.
Yeah, there's a few different thoughts there that I'd like to add that one is that there was a
common refrain from people that worked on different aspects of Apollo that it wasn't going to fail
because of me. That's what they would always say. Like, I'm going to do, I'm going to be excellent
in my job, whether I'm the person behind the person behind the person. And it's not about the
rugged individualism that you talked about. It's about everybody just being excellent in what they
do because the stakes are very high. And somehow, like, especially in our current political situation,
it's very complex. The arrows were pointed in roughly the same direction of people's purpose.
And that is not easy to do. I mean, if you think about all those to use your metaphor of multiple
processors, is they're all working against each other or they're working in counterproductive to
one another competing against each other, it's still the same amount of processing power. You're
not going anywhere. So really, it's that common purpose and like the words that are used often
now, like it's a nation committing itself to doing something. And then people allowing their
patriotism and their self identity within that process to be at their best and to focus on that
goal. You know, how did that happen? And there's been a lot of history that's been written up to
try to figure out how that happened. Like that transcends a four-year presidential term,
that transcends any kind of been fighting for funding within Congress. And it wasn't clean.
Like, this is another really important point. It wasn't like, oh, that was back when we all had
common purpose. Like, no, no, no, no, no, no, people were fighting constantly. And even within NASA,
if you look into the history and the depth of the kind of deep dive that I've gone into,
it was a lot of bureaucracy. There was a lot of people that wanted, you know, no, I want my team
to be doing this, not that other team. There's a lot of competitiveness and like even some of
the top people that did a lot of the science operations in Johnson Space Center said like,
every time I wanted to get something done, I just talked to the head of Johnson Space Center
and went past everybody. I don't know what the right way was that you were supposed to do it,
but that's how I did it, you know, things like that. You know, so I think that's a really important
lesson because with the distance in history, you can be tempted to look back and go. This is when
everybody was different than they are now. And you know, that leaves the self doubt like,
oh, could we ever do that again? I could, it's really messy from my desk. And it looks so nice and
clean with, you know, pretty music in the documentary about the past. Well, if you listen to that 30
track audio, there's like people getting in trouble for sleeping in and almost missing their shift.
There's someone asking where the overtime cards are because they want to clock some overtime.
You know, they were good at their jobs and nothing untoward ever happened in the recordings. I can
assure you that I came across anyway. But they're normal people. They're just like the people that
work in Mission Control today. I think all that stuff together both makes Apollo something for
us to focus on, but it also just hopefully it's inspirational that we had something like, hey,
what can we do if we decide to get past our differences and try to have a common purpose?
Thank you for entertaining my question there about what this means. And I appreciate your answer.
I appreciate it to the degree that I get why this is awesome, better now than I ever have in my
entire life. This was one small step forward for you in conversation and one giant step forward
for me in understanding why this thing was amazing and what it means. Thanks for indulging that.
Oh, thanks for giving me the opportunity to preach.
It was a good sermon. Apollo in realtime.org. Go check out what Ben has done. Is there any way
people can support you? Nope, just go and enjoy yourself. That's awesome. Sweet. Ben, this is
awesome, man. Thank you so much for joining us. We really appreciate it. Hey, no pleasure.
This episode of Notre Dame Questions is sponsored by HelloFresh. And we have a ridiculous promo
code. Matt, I just want you to kind of tell me how this works because if I'm reading this correctly,
10 free meals, including free shipping. I don't see where I'm needed in that equation. I think
you just spelled it out. So here's the thing. The human body requires food in order to function.
And if you don't put some in there in rather regular intervals, you die. We don't want that for
you. We don't want that for anyone. So you're going to want to eat food. Take it from us. We've
been food eaters our whole lives. Well, it turns out that food costs money because of the production
effort that goes into it. So if there were an opportunity for you to get a thing you need to
sustain your existence and it were free and you could get 10 of those things, I think that would
be a thing you want. And that's why I like this promotion there. Dude, that was wonderful.
Thank you for doing it that way. That was fantastic. Yeah. No, here's the deal. This is a
ridiculous offer. And I'm sold on HelloFresh. Great food comes straight to your door. You got
all the ingredients you need. You get a little card with easy step-by-step instructions and you
get to cook. Like you get to learn how to do the steps to make an amazing meal. And when you get
done, you like want to pat yourself on the back because you feel like you did an amazing thing
because you did. It's awesome. So here's the deal. The promo code. You go to hellofresh.com
slash 10 NDQ. That's 10. I'll give it to you phonetically. It's no dumb questions. NDQ. But
it's 10 November delta Quebec. And the promo code is 10 NDQ at checkout. And that's 10 free meals
including free shipping. This is the deal you need to do. It's amazing. We love it. Our family
loves it. Well, my family, I guess we're kind of family. We don't technically have the same literal
family, but we overlap quite a bit. I mean, it's good. Yeah, it's pretty good. And before we get out
of here, one of the things I got to say that I'm really liking about HelloFresh is it seems
like they are always expanding the menu and coming up with more ways to scratch the food
itches that people would have. So they've got low calorie options. They've got limited carb
options. They've got vegetarian options. They got the fish-a-terian options that people are liking
more and more. It's called Pescatarian, right? Yeah, fish-a-terian. I don't know. Dude, I just
catch the fish. And then I tell them how much I admire their beauty. And then I put them back
into nature. Other people like to eat the fish. I can respect that, but it's a confusing term for
me. So the thing about it is, you know, as people think more about what they put in their bodies,
HelloFresh has been on the exact same trajectory thinking more about what you put in your bodies.
So pretty much whatever you're doing food-wise, there's a HelloFresh that's going to fit with that.
And on top of that, it's super sustainable. Smart people who research these things get to
think like, well, I mean, how does this delivery thing work? Would that actually be a savings or a
net drain on everything in terms of resources? And according to the University of Michigan,
it is actually a net saver in terms of sustainability and resources.
More than that, though, it's the money thing too, right? If you do this right, it cuts down your
grocery bill by saving up to 40% instead of shopping at your local store. But like, if you think about
the promo code, it saves 100% on those 10 meals. Because math. Because math. And remember,
you have to eat. It's absolutely mandatory. So it seems like this is a real opportunity to
link your needs with tremendous financial benefit. Okay, to get your mitts on America's number one
meal kit delivery service. Hello, Fresh. You got a HelloFresh.com.
Let's do this, Matt. I just want to see how in sync we are because there is a delay between me
and you. I want to know if we can say the promo code at the same time together and overlap.
You ready? Dustin, in the past, we've done, and by we, I mean me, I think some of the best
advertising jingle work in the history of podcast advertising for HelloFresh.
Possibly the world. Yes, I'm with you. Possibly. This time around, I think we should do something
that is a little less ambitious, but simply two tone, 16th century, Gregorian chant style
reading of the jingle. Okay. I believe we've got this. Okay, I'm down. Let's do it.
So simply two pitches. I think that's the correct intro.
Hello Fresh.com. Yep. Okay. You got it? Yep.
And we're going to go to HelloFresh.com slash 10 and DQ.
Like that? Yeah. Well, let's make it sound like it's in a cathedral. So that's going to be your
pitch. Yeah, that's it. Okay. I got mine ready. I'm mad at us right now. Okay, I'm ready. Let's do it.
Ready? Hello Fresh.com slash and DQ. You're doing it wrong. It's 10 and DQ.
Just follow my lead. Yeah. Hello Fresh.com slash 10 and DQ.
This is awful. We're going to do the whole thing. Wait, I'll follow your lead again.
We got to do the whole thing. Ready? Ready? Yes. Go. Hello Fresh.com slash 10 and
DQ and use code 10 and DQ for 10 meals, including free shipping.
Why? They should get Hello Fresh. Hello Fresh.
All right. Let's talk about space. Was that awesome or what? Yeah, that was excellent.
It was moving. I wasn't goofing around it. It made me cry, man. I know. And I've seen that.
Well, I haven't seen that footage. That footage was actually the most boringest footage of all the
footage I've ever seen of the moon landing. But it was, I think, seeing all the anticipation
and understanding that if it took six years to just reestablish the conversation around it,
something snapped for me. No, snap makes it sound like it's bad. Something clicked for me today
in terms of valuing and appreciating properly appraising the significance of that achievement.
Yeah. What was really interesting was seeing the people back in mission control react real
time to when the landing happened. And you see Gene Krantz take a real big pull on a cigarette
and just put it out in the ashtray right there right before landing and you're like,
that dude's about to have a heart attack. But Gene Krantz is known to be like just ice water in the
veins, just total professional is amazing. I've never seen anything like it. So Apollo in real
time.org. The thing about getting into some of the stuff that you're into is that I wouldn't even
think to ask the question, the tensions that would lead to those innovations have not occurred to me.
As soon as you explain the tension to me, then my little hamster wheel can start turning in my head
and I will get eventually to what the problem is going to be or it's going to make sense at least
at the beginning level. But that's part of what's fun about doing these episodes where we deep dive
into projects you're doing on Smarter Every Day is not just the solution. It's the process of you
leading me to a place where I even get why you asked the question in the first place. And this is
another one of those. I love what it does for my brain and I hope it has a similar effect on the
third chair. With the beauty of this particular problem is that we have the benefit of your
discipline, which is history. And because these problems were solved in the past, we get to go
back and ask, well, how did you solve it? And why did you solve it this way instead of a different
way? Because there are reasons. For example, they may have been limited by processing technology.
They may have been limited by an inertial measurement unit, you know, data rate, for example. So if we
talk to Wayne Audinger, who was an engineer on the LLTV program, and we ask him why he did certain
things, we may be able to reproduce what he did in a better way, because we do have the technology
that can do the thing he couldn't do in the past. Or you might find out that technology's
technology, that was the best you could do it. Yeah, keep it simple, stupid. And maybe what they've
got is awesome. And what they did is awesome. What I love is that you're describing a historical
principle that should be one of the four or five principles of understanding the past that everyone,
everyone should take with them when they go and think about what people before us did.
But we don't. There are these two forces that are at work in our brains when we look back
any further than last week. Force number one is forgetfulness. We're really usually up to date
on what's going on right now. We're more up to date and can better reconstruct today than we can
reconstruct what happened to seven days ago. You think about what your degradation curve looks like
for detail memory? It's a pretty quick taper, right? Yeah, you need hooks to remember stuff from a
week ago, two weeks ago, three weeks ago, four weeks ago, everything else just goes downstream
to stay sane. So you got that one thing that happens in our brains when we try to evaluate and
think about and interpret history. But the other thing you have is the assumption that now is better
and smarter. Chronological snobbery is what C.S. Lewis calls that. Yeah, and we've talked about
that before. And part of it is a chronological snobbery of ethics. We're much more ethically
enlightened than anybody was before us. Well, I take exception to that. I go, yeah, we've accomplished
some things, but we didn't defeat slavery and get women the vote. People who are now dead did that
and they deserve moral credit for that. So no, I don't think we are better than them for all of the
ills of the past. There was also somebody dead who came along and made those ills go away.
That assumption that we are morally superior to people of the past. I don't think that's a safe
assumption. I think that assumption could be better stated as there are things we generally
hold to now that are morally better than things that some people generally held to in the past.
But there are also exceptions and we're in no good position to self criticize. We don't know
why we suck now. The people a generation or two or five from now will be crystal clear on what we
were stupid about, just like we're crystal clear on what we think people were stupid about five
generations ago. Hopefully people five generations from now will be maybe a little bit more gentle
on us than we are right now on the people who came before us. But whether they are not,
this idea of moral superiority historically and intellectual superiority historically is
something that we just can't seem to help bringing with us to thinking about history.
We don't give people in the past the benefit of the doubt. And maybe it's because we know we
never have to face them or argue with them. But if we do what you just did with this project,
what Ben just did, which is assume the sanity and intelligence of all the people you are studying,
your history inquiry works way better. Everything makes more sense. Everything clicks. But if you
start by assuming they were dumb or immoral, their actions don't make much sense. And so
you're telling me you look back on this thing. And what you're seeing is engineering decisions
that could take you two years to reconstruct the parameters within which that person made
that decision. But you'd be wasting your two years because by the time you get done with it,
all you'd be like, Oh, yeah, that guy was right. Yep. You knew the playing field and you nailed it.
Well, what you're saying brings up two thoughts in my mind. And they both have to do with people
that I interviewed for this video. Number one was Ben Feist who we just interviewed.
So the beauty of his project here is that it brought to light that these people are real people.
Like Ben said, when we watched the documentary, there's soft music playing and it's heroic and
amazing. But this task was taken on by normal people. And they did amazing things. And by listening
to them on console, we can hear their normalness. And we can hear all the things they were dealing
with. And so that's fascinating and amazing. But another thing that really, really struck me
when I was making this video is speaking to the engineer who helped make the LLTV,
Mr. Wayne Audinger. I asked him a question because when I look back at this as an engineer today,
with more computational power in my cell phone in my hand, and they had on the entire system
that went to the moon, I look back and I see my grandfather's slide rule, you know, and he worked
on test stands for the rockets and stuff. And I'm like, man, I think they were just better.
I think they were better. But I actually asked Mr. Audinger that. And he was there. So he's an
authority on the topic. And if it's cool, I would like to play his response to my question. Is that
okay? If I play that real quick? More than cool, please. Mr. Anagir, I know that I need to let you
go. But I would like to ask you two more questions. And these are big picture questions. Thank you
for how generous you've been with your time. But first big picture question is, so back in the day,
the engineers and scientists on this program did amazing things with limited electronics.
Right. So do you think that engineers in the 50s and 60s were better than engineers today?
No, no, I think we all had our unique place in the history and they'll continue to be a,
you know, new challenges met. That'll be innovation that continues. And part of it's because they can
build on our shoulders. They can learn from what we did and adapt to the technology and self-worth.
The way he says no, like I remember in the moment, you know, because I, here I am sitting in an
engineer today and I'm thinking about, I have access to finite element analysis, computational
fluid dynamics, all kind of like, we can solve crazy problems today with computers. And they,
they couldn't, but they did. And they've literally invented integrated circuits to do this. And so,
I looked back at what all they were doing and I thought, man, they're just better. And then to
hear, not just him say no, engineers weren't better, but the way he said it, no, no, no,
that was part of his soul. He meant that. I don't know. It was just a really neat look.
This whole thing was a really neat look back into the complexities of the problem, but also
the men and women that rose to the occasion and got it done and their normalness. And I'm looking
forward to the Artemis program to see normal people do the same thing again, to ultimately go
further and beyond and do like Mr. Ottinger said and build on their shoulders. If you'll indulge
me, I'd like to end on one more thing. So, I would like you to verbally describe to me, I'm going to
close my eyes and I'm in orbit around the moon. I would like you to take me all the way to the
ground on the moon. Tell me what I need to do with my thrusters, where I need to point them
and how I need to fire them. Go. All right, game on. No, I'm serious. Yeah. Okay. No, here we go.
We're in orbit. I'm going to start with an 8-bit video game view of this. So, we have a camera
mounted on the front of our spacecraft and we have the partial sphere of the moon in the lower
third of the shot. Okay. Space is in the upper two thirds. We are falling toward the moon at a
rapid rate, but we are also moving forward at a rapid enough rate that that collapse is not truly
felt. We are in orbit. There is a separation that occurs with our lunar lander. I can picture the
little burst of air. Like you see, anytime an airlock gets broken in any kind of space or sci-fi show,
I can picture our gumdrop shaped grimace lunar lander module legs out being nudged forward.
So it is being moved forward, but at a slight angle of declination down toward that orb of the moon
that we're seeing in the lower third of the shot. The spacecraft continues to move forward
and we see that lunar lander briefly come into our shot, but fade out of the bottom of the shot
down toward the moon as the spacecraft continues on in orbit. Cut to a second shot that is more of
a side view with that lunar lander feet out headed toward the surface. It's not moving straight down
toward the surface like a lunar elevator. It's moving at a, I would say a relatively shallow angle
coming down toward the surface, maybe not like an airplane landing angle, but shallower than a
straight drop. To begin with, it's going parallel to the surface of the moon.
Almost parallel though, right? To begin with, we're in orbit. Oh, in orbit. Sure, sure, sure.
Yeah, we're still in orbit. So it's going parallel. You haven't fired a rocket yet.
No, I haven't fired a rocket yet. Like if you were to look at the side view of the moon as a circle,
we're in a bigger circle around the moon. But this next orbit that we've initiated
by the way we separated, it's putting it in a lower orbit than the spacecraft even initially,
even if just barely a lower orbit, correct? No, no, no, no at all.
So they're still in identical position. Yeah, yeah. Okay, I thought you explained it that
the separation caused the initial nudge toward the lower orbit at which point then we fire lightly
to get into the declination that we want. Okay, so we're there. So we have fired a rocket and we are
controlling our pitch using the what you call the pulses.
Attitudes control thrusters. That's what I was going to say almost exactly except none of those
words. And so what we have now is whoever is on the comms inside is monitoring how quickly
we are in decline. So is that in feet per second? 15 feet per second?
It's whatever you want it to be. We can do first. Let's pretend that is. Yeah, feet per second. Yep.
Okay, obviously we're trying to control that speed with two factors. We have the ability to
slow ourselves with a rocket and we have the ability to slow ourselves or to reduce the force of impact
by coming in at an angle instead of coming in straight down. Is that correct? Yeah, okay.
So I don't know, we've got a landing angle that we've committed to. We're maintaining that all
the way through. And as we get closer, we are correcting with those thrusters to keep our
lunar lander positioned in such a way that it's going to touchdown not destructively. And we didn't
quite get to this point, but I assume that we're going to fire harder as we get closer to the surface
so that instead of coming down like an airplane, back legs of the lander first, then we touch down,
excuse me, then we touch down with the front legs of the lander. That wouldn't work. It's not
built for that. It's how wheels, these are pegs, right? I mean, these are these are feet.
So instead, we've got a slow to a place where we're not going to have a devastating touchdown,
but we've also got to stabilize with those pulse bursts so that we're touching down effectively
all feet simultaneously. Mm hmm. Yeah. Is that it? We're on the moon, man. Okay, sweet. Let's go get
a scoop of dirt. I want one of those. Nice job explaining if I can even get in the zip code of
something I know literally nothing about, then you've explained it well.
I really enjoyed processing all this because we kind of spent a lot of time in your area of
expertise, the history side. Yeah. But it also touches mine. So we're in that like sweet,
Venn diagram place and the queue sliver. Yeah. I like that spot. But I really enjoyed
this one thing that Ben said, and I was hoping we could end on this. Is that cool with you?
Yeah. Let's give him the last word.
The looking back has shown us that this is what could happen when 400,000 people all with a common
purpose work together to make something happen. It really shows the best of what we can be when
we work together.
